steps.text: Check the pesticide information for currency before use.
Use pesticides safely and follow label directions.
Construct buildings with preventive design and maintain them.
Implement daily pest management programs.
Comply with federal and state regulations.
Maintain short grass and trim shrubs.
Pave access and ensure proper drainage.
Create 18-24 inch gravel strip around foundation.
Place night-lights at least 30 feet from doors.
Keep framing at least four inches from walls.
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam.
Coat concrete floors for better sanitation.
Use acid-proof or brick floors for wet processing areas.
Seal wall materials like concrete, brick, or tile.
Prevent hollow panel-type walls from becoming insect quarters.
Make roofs smooth and free of standing water.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass for preventive maintenance.
Perform regular inspections to identify potential issues.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage.
Reduce outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps for nonchemical management.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
Maintain bait stations for pesticide management of rodents.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites for pesticide management of insects.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate for pesticide management of birds.
Rodent-proof all openings for preventive maintenance of buildings.
Screen windows.
Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Keep all areas free of loose materials.
Clean structures and equipment frequently.
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent traps near doors and map their locations.
Use air curtains at doors.
Use deterrents for birds on roosting sites.
Implement pesticide management as per policy.
Use space treatments with nonresiduals for raw commodities.
Use crack and crevice treatments with residuals for raw commodities.
Apply spot treatments as necessary.
Perform fumigation when required.
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program in the Processing Area.
Use rodent traps near doors if needed in the Processing Area.
Ensure proper sanitation in the Processing Area.
Use space, spot, crack and crevice, and contact treatments as appropriate in Packaging Areas.
Form an inspection committee with the highest company official as chairman and including all department heads.
Create a successful in-plant sanitation program.
Review existing activities and compile a list of deficiencies.
Wear identifiable uniforms and carry necessary tools during inspections.
Conduct thorough inspections in new places and record all defects.
Distribute notes to department heads for immediate action.
Correct defects immediately.
Meet at the end of an inspection cycle to review notes, address uncorrected items, and assign realistic correction dates.
Examine obscure areas using a flashlight.
Observe suspect stock on a flat surface.
Inspect areas under and inside equipment.
Look for problem areas opposite cleaning.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Reward good sanitation to encourage cooperation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm for a fresh perspective.
Inspect the warehouse with an 18-inch space between pallets and walls.
Maintain housekeeping standards in raw product receiving.
Implement a reliable stock rotation method.
Follow a written inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Determine regulatory factors for postharvest systems.
Identify factors that regulate storability.
Check moisture content as a regulatory factor.
Check temperatures during storage. Maintain temperatures between 65°F and 95°F.
Monitor temperature changes and avoid sudden drops.
Inspect stored materials regularly.
Minimize insect access by inspecting incoming materials and designing buildings.
Use visual inspection as a monitoring tool.
Identify high-risk foods based on age, source, and temperature.
Perform visual inspection for open packages and poor sanitation.
Check for insects near lights.
Use yellow or sodium arc lights outdoors to reduce attraction.
Determine trap placement based on time of year and temperature profiles.
Place one trap per 4,000-5,000 square feet in high-risk areas.
Examine trends in trap catches over time to modify management practices.
Consider using alternatives like heat treatments, temperature manipulation, and improved monitoring for future applications.
Inspect bagged commodities.
Identify pests.
Determine the extent of a problem.
Evaluate a treatment method.
Use pitfall traps or traps that deflect dust in dusty areas.
Adapt trap placement to changing temperature gradients throughout the year.
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility.
Start with a wide grid (one trap per 100,000 cubic feet)
Move traps or add more to the suspect area if pests are detected.
Visually search areas where the most insects were captured.
Look for increases in numbers from one period to the next to interpret catches.
Construct structure to keep out pests.
Implement non-chemical control methods.
Carry out bulk seed storage chemical control.
Apply chemical control in warehouses.
Execute rodent control program.
Perform bird control.
Read the label before using a pesticide.
Apply pesticides only in accordance with the label instructions.
Identify food, food processing facilities, nonfood areas, and food areas.
Understand different types of residual applications: general.
Apply insecticide to limited areas where insects are present but won't contact food or workers.
Perform crack and crevice application in food areas.
Ensure pesticide regulations are followed.
Determine if food product contains unapproved pesticide or residue above tolerance level.
Destroy adulterated food product.
Check pesticide label for approved sites.
Apply pesticide only on approved sites.
Obtain USDA-approved pesticides for meat plants.
Avoid using residuals in production areas.
Use residuals only as crack and crevice treatments in sealed areas.
Ensure safety of workers, facility employees, and food product.
Gather information from labels and MSDS.
Perform a facility survey.
Identify beetles and moths' life cycles.
Determine differences between Almond Moth and Indianmeal Moth.
Identify type of moth or beetle present.
Inspect food surfaces for signs of webbing or damage.
Apply appropriate control method based on pest identification and food source.
Identify cockroach species based on appearance and preferred habitat.
Implement control measures based on identified species.
Remove breeding sites for larvae by addressing sanitation issues.
Control infestations of ants by treating their nests.
Control infestations of ants using barrier sprays.
Control infestations of ants using baits.
Control infestations of bees and wasps by treating their nests at night.
Identify types of pests: Booklice, Silverfish and Firebrats, Crickets, Ground Beetles, Sowbugs and Pillbugs.
Determine pest habitats: Damp locations for Booklice, Silverfish and Firebrats; Lights for Crickets; Soil for Ground Beetles.
Identify rat or mouse signs.
Examine droppings for freshness and shape.
Observe runways along walls.
Look for cleared paths outdoors or greasy runways indoors.
Identify signs of rodents such as rubmarks, burrows, tracks, and urine.
Store products on pallets away from walls.
Use a strip of gravel around buildings to deter burrowing.
Seal all openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats.
Use rodent-resistant materials like hardware cloth, sheet metal, and concrete.
Pay attention to doors, windows, vents, drainpipes, foundations, and utility lines.
Place toxic dust in runways for tracking powders.
Avoid using poison where it may contaminate food.
Select appropriate bait for rodents.
Understand different generations of toxicants and their effects.
Provide preferred food base for bait.
Prebait for several days before using acute toxicants.
Place tamper-proof bait stations.
Position bait stations every 10 feet for mice and 20 feet for rats.
Describe types of traps: snap traps, live-capture cage traps, wind-up multiple-catch traps (for mice).
Place traps where rodents will encounter them.
Use many traps, placed close together for mice.
Bait traps effectively with good baits like peanut butter, raisins, nutmeats, and bacon.
Secure bait to the trap's trigger.
Introduce information about sticky glue boards.
Explain cats and dogs are generally not effective for controlling established rodent populations.
Describe the Compressed Air Sprayer as the 'workhorse' of pest control.
Inspect and maintain the tank, pump, hose, valve, and nozzle.
Clean equipment after each use.
Check gaskets and valves regularly.
Do not leave pressurized equipment unattended.
Select appropriate nozzle type based on application.
Use thermal fogging in warehouses.
Ensure safety by turning off pilot lights and knowing cubic footage.
Understand difference between mists and fogs.
Apply Ultra Low Dosage (ULD) method carefully.
Wear appropriate respiratory protection.
Use chemical cartridge respirators for low concentration gases.
Use gas masks with canisters for higher concentration gases and fumigants.
Air-supply: Obtain clean air from an external source or a tank.
Ensure respirators for pesticides are approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
Maintain a proper fit.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Beard care: Wear a beard with caution as it may interfere with a tight seal.

constraints.text: The presence of flying insects indicates an active infestation.
Frass is a sign of insect activity.
High moisture levels attract certain types of pests.
